thread.title: Glitch Halts New York Stock Exchange Trading
thread.title_full: Glitch Halts New York Stock Exchange Trading

title: Glitch Halts New York Stock Exchange Trading
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 8, 2015, 19:32 BST - UK Markets closed Glitch Halts New York Stock Exchange Trading By (c) Sky News 2015 | Sky News â€“ 13 minutes ago View Photo 

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended trading in all stocks because of a "technical issue" that has caused havoc on the world's largest equity exchange. 
The disruption began at about 11:30am local time, but did not appear to affect other stock markets. 
The NYSE said in tweets: "The issue we are experiencing is an internal technical issue and is not the result of a cyber breach. 
"We chose to suspend trading on NYSE to avoid problems arising from our technical issue. 
"NYSE-listed securities continue to trade unaffected on other market centers." 
The exchange, which has a market capitalisation of about $20trn, said all open orders would be cancelled. 
Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said the NYSE halt and a glitch that temporarily grounded all United Airlines flights earlier in the day were apparently not related to "nefarious" activity. 
NYSE President Tom Farley told CNBC it had been a "tough day", but he was confident the market would open before the end of the day. 
The Nasdaq exchange, also based in New York, said in a tweet that its systems were operating normally. 
The Nasdaq halted trades for three hours in August 2013 due to technical problems. 
The White House said it was monitoring Wednesday's situation, along with the Treasury Department. 
Josh Earnest, White House press secretary, said there was "no indication malicious actors were involved". 
The Securities and Exchange Commission, the US financial markets regulator, said it was also keeping an eye on the NYSE halt. 
The Wall Street Journal meanwhile said its website had suffered "technical difficulties". 
It was unclear if that issue was caused by a surge in readers looking for information about the NYSE breakdown. 
More follows...
